title: feat: add `confirmation_prompt` and `hide_input` to protected CLI prompts

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: cli
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Command Line Interface (CLI)

body:
# Description

This PR adds both the `hide_input` and `confirmation_prompt` for the CLI arguments/options `password` and `api_key` to make sure those are somehow protected, as it's a nice practice to hide those fields.

Note that the `confirmation_prompt` is just set for the `password`, as the API Key tends to be longer and can be easily retrieved, while the password needs to be remembered and cannot be checked at any point since the creation.

Closes #3679

**Type of change**

title: [DOCS] Write a prompt engineering tutorial

labels.name: type: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body: After a discussion related to [this recent tutorial](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/guides/llms/examples/fine-tuning-openai-rag-feedback.html#Evaluating-base-vs-fine-tuned-with-human-preference-data), I suggested that a similar tutorial showcasing a GPT3 **prompt engineering** workflow with argilla would be exciting for a lot of people. [This paper](https://aclanthology.org/2023.acl-industry.24/) from the ACL 2023 industry track found that prompt engineering - if done well - can be both cheaper and lead to better performance (in terms of saving time and money) than fine-tuning for a use case in customer service. This would serve as a terrific motivation for such a tutorial.

title: [FEATURE] Add search and replace functionality for the `FeedbackDataset` on the UI
body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendly.com/natalia-elvira/30min -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I think it could be handy to have a Search and Replace functionality via the UI that could apply to the whole dataset, instead of record by record.

Let me use the next records from an example dataset, altough this may apply to different cases:

![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/56895847/c908b724-16bf-47c8-af5e-8941282539aa)

![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/56895847/0c8ad44f-ffdd-4031-8883-9f63a508a7ed)

The dataset is made of lines of characters in a TV series, and includes extra information regarding what the character does in the scene between square brackets. I would like this "explanations" texts to be removed.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Some functionality to search and replace text, optionally using regular expressions, like the one you have in text editors (the following is an example in VSCode aflter typing Ctrl+H).

![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/56895847/71754a97-58c4-4cd4-94e1-6bb6f0c0033a)

It should apply to all the text fields in the dataset, and I think to the pending records only.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

This process can easily be done in pandas, for example, using the following function:

```python
df[column].str.replace(re.compile("\[(.*?)\]"), "", regex=True)
```
Where the `column` could be any of the `fields` in the `FeedbackDataset`. 

- It could be done before uploading the dataset to argilla.
- Download the dataset, process it and load it again.

**Additional context**

body:
# Description

The aim of this feature is to enable highlighting for the Feedback dataset annotations view. 

## Solution proposal

Since the search for Feedback datasets allows only searches by terms, and the search results do not include any info on highlighting results (and it's not planned since depends on the backed search engine and the current one could change in the future), the highlighting will be easily resolved on the frontend side (based on the input search text).

So text for record inputs will be processed to highlight terms matching the search.

Additionally, this should work when the record field shows a rendered markdown (`use_markdown=True`) (need to validate this with @damianpumar and @leiyre

body: **Describe the bug** As a follow up of https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/3405, I've realised that the maximum number of characters of the field titles is 500, but when setting a title of N consecutive characters, then the side-panel with the questions is also lost. I assume this may lead to potential conflicts on the following: * Field Titles * Question Titles * Question Descriptions Just in case you also want to check/explore other scenarios. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behaviour: 1. Deploy Argilla v1.15.0 2. Add a `FeedbackTask` dataset 3. Go to the `FeedbackTask` dataset settings and set the title of a field to N consecutive characters 4. Go back to the record view and see that the questions disappear **Expected behaviour** The field title to be automatically stripped or separated with a hyphen when reaching the end of the width so as not to continue. **Screenshots** **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS [e.g. iOS]: macOS - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Arc (based in Chromium) - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.15.0 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: N/A - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: argilla:v1.15.0

title: Align the default `visible_options`/`visible_labels` value with the options/labels list length
body:
The default value for `visible_labels`  is set to `20` even when the number of configured labels is lower. This can be confusing and could generate some inconsistent scenarios.

The Python client should adapt the logic to improve this as follows:
- Set `visible_labels=20` when `labels.length > 20`
- Set `visible_labels=None` when `labels.length <=20`

title: [BUG] Default `visible_options` value set to 20 in any scenario

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body: **Describe the bug** With the recent upgrade of the `FeedbackDataset` settings via the Argilla UI, I've noticed that the `visible_options` ranges always default to 20 (as in the backend), but what users see in the UI is not consistent as the range may be [3, 15], so the selector saying 20 is not correct. Additionally, we could remove the selector if there are less than 4 labels, as the minimum value in the backend will be 3, then in the scenarios were we have 2 or 3 labels, there's no option to tweak the `visible_options` value, so we can just remove it if not applicable. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behaviour: 1. Create a `FeedbackDataset` with a `LabelQuestion` either through the Python client or through the API, and make sure there are less than 20 labels defined (while keeping the default value for `visible_options` to 20) 2. Go to the settings in the Argilla UI of the created dataset 3. See that the `visible_options` selector indicates something like: range [3, 15], but the selector in the middle says 20 **Expected behavior** I'd expect to see the actual value, rather than the default, since when having under 20 labels, the range can just be [3, 19], so the default should be the max if default is 20 but there are less than 20 options e.g. 19; and the visible options bar should disappear if we have 2 or 3 labels, as otherwise the range looks like [2, 3] or [3, 3], but in both cases the min and the max values for `visible_options` is 3. **Screenshots** **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS [e.g. iOS]: macOS - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Arc (based in Chromium) - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: latest - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: N/A - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: N/A

title: [BUG] Argilla server endpoints built with `Enum`s are wrong in `python>=3.11`

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
**Describe the bug**
`python==3.11` introduced a change in the `Enum` classes for accessing the value of an enum:

```python
from enum import Enum

class MyEnum(str, Enum):
    FOO = "foo"

# python <= 3.11
print(MyEnum.FOO) # foo

# python >= 3.11
print(MyEnum.FOO) # MyEnum.FOO
```

This is causing that when the server is executed using `python>=3.11` the name of endpoints like `POST /api/datasets/{name}/TextClassification:bulk` is `POST /api/datasets/{name}/TaskType.text_classification:bulk`

https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/540b9a6bb3fd469d86f5445b3a0b5f509741887d/src/argilla/server/apis/v0/handlers/text_classification.py#L65-L66

Then, the Python client will try to call `POST /api/datasets/{name}/TextClassification:bulk` and it will get an error.

**Expected behavior**
Argilla server has the correct endpoints when executed using Python 3.11

**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.14.1
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]:

title: [FEATURE] Add `hide_input=True` in `password` and `api_key` args

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: cli
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Command Line Interface (CLI)

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Some CLI commands ask the user to introduced either the `password` or the `api_key` via prompt, and the field is not hidden, which is not a good practice, as usually those fields are hidden for security issues, so we should add `hide_input=True` in all the `typer.Option` args that relate to a protected field.

More information at https://typer.tiangolo.com/tutorial/options/password/#a-password-prompt

**Describe the solution you'd like**

e.g. for `argilla users create`

```bash
$ python -m argilla users create --username argilla
Password: *********
```

title: [FEATURE] Move server related CLI tasks under the  `argilla.server.tasks` module

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: cli
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Command Line Interface (CLI)

body:
The latest changes include new improvements in the CLI capabilities, allowing execution management operations to remote Argilla servers.

These new commands require a login step which is unnecessary for the older ones (database-related, user-related, and server-running related). 

So, we can clearly separate server-specific tasks (`database migrate`, `database user create`, or `server`). This separation should be reflected in the codebase, moving those related to the server side under de module `argilla.server.tasks`. And make them available for the command Argilla CLI if the server modules were installed.

title: :construction: POC change component from option api to composition api

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body:
- Change QuestionsForm and QuestionHeader components from `optionApi` to `compositionApi`
- move business logic inside external composables in the domain application
Note:
- to get the value of a reactive `variable` inside the setup hook, we need to pass through `variable.value` (see `questionAreCompletedCorrectly.value`)
- In vue3, bus event have been removed. that's means it's not possible to use `$root.$on`, `$root.$emit`, `$root.$on`.
The vue community recomend to not use bus event or use an external librairy as `mitt` (see [official documentation](https://github.com/developit/mitt#install))
- between Vue 2 and 3, some hooks have been replaced : 
          `created` => `setup`
          `mounted` => `onMounted`
          `destroyed` => `onUnMounted`


Next step : 
=> replace native bus event from nuxt by `mitt` or manage logic with `store`

**Type of change**

- Refactor (change restructuring the codebase without changing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- Feedback task

title: Add visible options/labels validation to avoid values under "3"
body:
At some point in the specs definition for label and multilabel questions, the decision of a lower limit of 3 was set. This value tackles some use cases for binary questions or questions with a low number of choices.  But in general, there is not much sense in allowing values under 3 (a least 2 for binary questions).

The backend/sdk should add this  validation for label and multi-label questions.

title: feat: 3615 feature update openai fine tuning with gpt 35 turbo 0613 to argillatrainer
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

I worked on adding chat-completion support to the ArgillaTrainer.

We can now fine-tune our models for the `TrainingTaskForChatCompletion` with `openai`.

I assumed that the `TrainingTaskForChatCompletion` would require a `chat-turn-role-content` format as `str-str-str-str`. This should be done because each conversational chain needs to be able to be retraced in the correct order and based on the user roles that might have been speaking. For example, in OpenAI we can have 3 types of roles, but I can also image that there might be multi-user conversations in the future.

```python
import argilla as rg
from argilla.feedback import ArgillaTrainer, TrainingTask

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    guidelines="Please, read the question carefully and try to answer it as accurately as possible.",
    fields=[
        rg.TextField(name="question"),
        rg.TextField(name="answer"),
    ],
    questions=[
        rg.RatingQuestion(
            name="answer_quality",
            description="How would you rate the quality of the answer?",
            values=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
        ),
        rg.TextQuestion(
            name="answer_correction",
            description="If you think the answer is not accurate, please, correct it.",
            required=False,
        ),
    ]
)
from datasets import load_dataset

# load and inspect a dataset from the Hugging Face Hub
hf_dataset = load_dataset('databricks/databricks-dolly-15k', split='train[:100]')

records = [rg.FeedbackRecord(fields={"question": record["instruction"], "answer": record["response"]}) for record in hf_dataset if record["category"]=="open_qa"]
dataset.add_records(records)
counter = 0

def func(record):
    from uuid import uuid4
    chat_id = str(uuid4())
    question = record["question"]
    answer = record["answer"]
    data = (chat_id, "1", "user", question)
    answer = (chat_id, 2, "assistant", answer)

    record = [data, answer]

    return record

task = TrainingTask.for_chat_completion(formatting_func=func)

trainer = ArgillaTrainer(
    dataset=dataset,
    task=task,
    framework="openai"
)
trainer.train("my-test-model")
```

Closes #3615

title: [FEATURE] Add variable after `rg.init` to see running Argilla version

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Sometimes the compatibility between the Python client and the server versions is an issue, and while internally we display a warning message when there's a mismatch, it would also be nice to be able to easily access the running version of Argilla through a variable right after the `rg.init`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(...)
print(f"Running Argilla version: {rg.__server_version__}")
```

**Additional context**

It would be also nice towards the integrations e.g. `ArgillaCallbackHandler` in `LangChain`, to be able to detect incompatibilities also via the Argilla Server, and not just via the Python client, as sometimes that can lead to potential conflicts as with the `metadata`.

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, we have the tests divided into unit and integration tests. The integration tests are still using mocks for the API. It would be good to deploy in the Github Workflow a temporary Argilla server to run the integration tests. This way, new integration tests could use this deployed Argilla server, avoiding adding more technical debt to the integration tests.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Using [service containers](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-containerized-services/about-service-containers) deploy the Argilla server docker image built for the PR, so the integration tests can be executed against it.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Deploy an environment in GCP, but I think service containers will be enough.

title: [DOCS/FEATURE] clarify usage of `RemoteFeedbackDataset` and local `FeedbackDataset`

labels.name: type: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

## Which page or section is this issue related to?
The issue originated here:
https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Atraining

> Yes that is what I meant but I did not get the memo about pull creating a local copy, but based on the current docs and the naming of the methods it is not very clear to me that:
> 
>     all changes are synced to the "golden" data in the remote Argilla instance
>     there is an option to work with a local copy via pull
>     we have the option to resync local and remote data via push_push_to_argilla

> I am just afraid that someone might by accident alter or even worse delete records from their deployment without being aware it is happening because normally you always work with local copies in Python. For me, syncing with the Argilla instance is a cool feature but more an optional one for people who know what they are doing or make it more explicit that it is happening.

For me, it is not really clear what the differences are between the usage of a remote and local version of the `FeedbackDataset`. @frascuchon agrees and suggested creating this issue to discuss this and come to a solution for this.

labels.name: type: bug

labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Continuous Integration (CI)

body:
# Description

This PR fixes the close pull request workflow that was failing because the value of the environment variable `GITHUB_REF` that it's supposed to have the following format `refs/pull/:prNumber/merge` (as documented [here](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/events-that-trigger-workflows#pull_request)) has the name of the target branch instead. Apparently, it's a GitHub bug that remains unfixed: https://github.com/actions/runner/issues/256

Instead of trying to get the PR number from the `GITHUB_REF`, this PR uses the `github.event.pull_request.number` variable.

Closes #3647

title: 🐛 [BUG] Improve annotation queue

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body:
When the user goes to the annotation page with specific criteria received from the backend a queue with records of the same status. However, when the user starts annotating, they might submit or discard records. During this process, the backend queue becomes different from what we have on the frontend side.

### Following the example below:
T0: (Initial state when the user arrives at the annotation page) (suppose that we receive a batch of three records from the backend)
Frontend queue: [pending1, pending2, pending3]
Backend queue: [pending1, pending2, pending3, pending4, pending5, ..., pendingN]

T1: (The user submits the first record in the queue)
Frontend queue: [submitted, pending, pending] ← When the user moves to page number four, we will send a request to the backend to get the content of page number four. Let's look at the state of the backend queue at that moment.
Backend queue: [submitted] - [pending2, pending3, pending4, pending5]  ← Here, pending4 never appears on the frontend because it is in the third position in the queue. We receive a new batch of records like that: [pending5, pending6, pending7]

### Proposed solution:
In this case, we send a request to the backend for the page based on the new queue. Assuming the previous example, we should request page number 3 instead of 4, since on the frontend we have only two records pending.

```
// Each record on the frontend corresponds to a page position. Sending the page number of the last record plus one could fix this issue when the user moves forward.
return lastRecord.page + 1

// If the user moves backward, we return the page number of the first record minus one. However, in this case, we only need to find one element, not a batch.
return firstRecord.page - 1
```

# Description

This PR adds the function `list_workspaces` so that it can be used as `import argilla as rg; rg.list_workspaces` since it was the only function under `Argilla` not included as part of the `__init__`. title: [FEATURE] ArgillaTrainer - allow passing `device` parameter

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: trainer
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Argilla Trainer

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Related: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3467#discussion_r1305230854

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I want users to be able to provide a device so the model can always be put on the right device, no matter whether that's cpu, gpu, mps, etc.:
```python
trainer = ArgillaTrainer(
    dataset=...,
    device="mps",
    ...
)
```

Currently we support `gpu_id` exclusively for spaCy. I propose that we replace `gpu_id` with `device`, which takes either an int, a string or a torch.device. Initially, we'll have:
```
if not device and gpu_id:
    warnings.warn(...)
    device = gpu_id
self.device = device
```
and spaCy will use the `self.device` as the `gpu_id`. That way we'll have backwards compatibility there.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
* Use `update_config` to change the device and/or move the device with `trainer._trainer.model.to("...")` or something.
* Make sure torch is compiled correctly so that cuda or mps is available.

**Additional context**
Should be implemented after #3467

---

- Tom Aarsen

body:
**Describe the bug**
I want to delete a dataset from a workspace and, to do that, I start by filtering datasets to keep only those from that workspace.
When deleting the dataset using the UI, a message "Warning: undefined" or "Error: undefined" appears. The dataset itself is deleted.
Sometimes, the error message is "Error: a workspace must be provided".
After the deletion, I am redirected to the home page, showing all the datasets and not only the ones from the specific workspace.

It seems that the error only occurs when I don't let Argilla load the label scheme or spot that the label scheme is undefined. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create an Argilla dataset where the label scheme in the UI is undefined/unsaved
2. Open the dataset settings and do not let the 'Labels' part time to load
3. Go to the danger zone and delete the dataset
4. See the error message near the green confirmation message

**Expected behavior**
The dataset should be deleted (that is fine) but without an error message.

title: fix: `RatingQuestion.values` validation when values out of range

# Description

This PR fixes a bug identified by @dvsrepo, introduced at https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3452, since we were just showing a `warnings.warn` message announcing the `DeprecationWarning`, but no version was scoped and the `RatingQuestion` was not valid on the Argilla Server side either, so the `warnings.warn` should have been a `ValidationError` instead.

title: [IMPROVE] Fields with empty title shall have exactly the same value as the user entered in the name field, without altering it

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
When a user creates a new dataset, he has the possibility to create fields with empty Title.

Currently, this title is being set to the same value as the name but Capitalized format from SDK code. This logic should be moved to the **backend** because the **frontend** should do exactly the same thing that the **SDK** do.

This is necessary to unify the business logic in one place.

Tasks:
- Move the SDK logic as-is to the backend.
- Remove the validation that the backend has when processing the field request, as the title may be optional.
- Think about what should be the correct format of the title, as ideally the value entered by the user should NOT be modified.

Examples: 
- If the user enters a field with name: FOO, the title should be FOO.
- If the user enters a field with name: foo, the title should be foo.
- If the user enters a field with name: fOo, the title must be fOo.
In short, the value the user entered should not be changed.

title: [BUG] Invalid value range for `RatingQuestion` not catched during Python SDK validation

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
Defining a rating question with this range `[0,1,2,3,4,5]` doesn't throw a validation error on the Python SDK instantiation, but then fails when pushing the dataset to Argilla and with an exception that doesn't not provide any indication of what went wrong.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**

```python
dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[rg.TextField(name="user-message"), rg.TextField(name="assistant-message")],
    questions=[
        rg.TextQuestion(name="response", title="Write a helpful, harmful, accurate response"),
        rg.RatingQuestion(name="question-rating", title="Rate the relevance of the user question", values=[0,1,2,3,4,5], required=False)
    ]
)
```
doesn't throw a validation error, but the following does:

```python
ds = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="argilla_assistant", workspace="admin")
```

```
Exception: Failed while adding the question 'question-rating' to the `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla with exception: 
Argilla server returned an error with http status: 422
Error details: [{'code': 'argilla.api.errors::ValidationError', 'params': {}}]
```
**Expected behavior**
I would expect the Python SDK to throw an easy to understand error message during instantiation, instead of not throwing any error and getting the error from the API with no explanation about the problem.

Related note: Besides catching this specific error on the SDKs side, which I assume is a bug: we should put more effort into providing useful, descriptive error messages on both sides (Python SDK, API)

**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version: 1.14.1
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:
 - Docker Image (optional): quickstart

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

# Description

This PR fix an issue in which the server returned a `422` when trying to update the response of a record with `draft` status.

# Description

This PR adds two new endpoints:

- `DELETE /api/v1/suggestions/{suggestion_id}`: allows to remove a specific suggestion

In addition, I moved the unit tests of the record endpoints to a class `TestSuiteRecords`.

Closes #3618

title: [BUG] Update response endpoint returning 422 when status sent is `draft`

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
**Describe the bug**
@damianpumar detected a bug in which the `PUT /api/v1/responses/{response_id}` endpoint returns a `422` HTTP status code when trying to update a response and the sent status is `draft`.

This bug is being caused because we don't have a `DraftResponseStatusCode` class:

https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/aeb5b8e9d1dbb52429bc3d1bec508c44659e7e9b/src/argilla/server/schemas/v1/responses.py#L50-L60

**Expected behavior**
The endpoint return a `200` HTTP status code when called and the sent status is `draft`.

title: [FEATURE] Allow changing `text` field in the UI for Text2Text records Dataset, at least for `Admin`/`Owner`
body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendly.com/natalia-elvira/30min -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Some of our data points need refinement in the input (text field). For example, we have a translation task (text2text records and dataset are perfect for our use case, we don't need FeedBack dataset for this task for now), but we cannot edit the text field in the UI.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The ability to edit in the UI the text for each record, even if it's only for `Admin`/`Owner` role. For now it's only possible to edit the ground truth.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I've considered creating a small app in streamlit that uses the python API to achieve this, as with the python API is 100% possible to load a record and update the text only, but having it in Argilla UI would be a plus.

I've also considered putting the entire record in the `annotation` field, just because it's editable in the app, and parse it in python, but obviously this is not optimal given that I'd have to leave the `text` practically empty, and it would be a hacky way of using the app

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

title: [FEATURE] Update `allowed_for_roles` when `admin` role is not sufficient

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

The current `allowed_for_roles` Python decorator just checks the role of the user, but in some cases, the policies defined in the API imply not just that the user has `admin` role, but have access to a `workspace`.

So we need to extend the `allowed_for_roles` decorator to also ensure that the `admin` has access to the workspace where the `RemoteFeedbackDataset`, `RemoteFeedbackRecords`, or `RemoteFeedbackRecord` are.
